messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Curt Sampson <yahoo_sucks@c...> wrote:
> On Sat, 22 Feb 2003, Lauren Bish wrote:
>
> > Well of course, all things need to change from time to time, and
should be
> > allowed to do so - but constantly changing interfaces, or
interfaces that
> > change drastically, are an indication that there is something
wrong - either
> > in the process or in the code.
>
> This seems to me tantmount to saying that something is wrong with
> agressive refactoring promoted by the XP process.
>
> I change interfaces all the time, but I consider this to be
something
> right, not something wrong. I think my process is good because I
don't
> need to consider whether an interface I'm developing now will be
> workable in the future; I just need to get it to work with what I
need
> now--a much simpler and faster job--and leave it at that. And it's
good
> for my code because it keeps my code smaller, more easily
modifiable,
> and less likely to have bugs.

Also on point is the fact that, as an Agilist, my goal is to deliver
the software that my client needs at delivery and not the software
that my client needed six months ago. To do that, I have to manage
change, rather than resist it. So it is with the code itself.

It is true that progress slows in the face of change, but only if
there is not an effective way to manage change. Tests are the safety
net that help us manage the risk of changing code; therefore, in the
presence of tests, change should be simple, even if not easy. In
other words, the tests enable refactoring, which enable us to adapt
to the changing needs of our customers.

Now it is also true that interfaces should converge to stability
over time; but forcing them to do so ignores important information.
There must be a reason why this natural convergence does not happen
in a given situation. Therein, perhaps, lies a problem that we need
to solve. Rather than ignore the problem or steamroller over it, we
should examine it and deal with it.

-- JBR.
